name: One of the first auteurs
description: A progenitor of modern film genres such as sci-fi, psychological thriller and serial killer films decades before such terms were coined, Austrian-born director Fritz Lang also enjoyed the occasional on-screen meta-moment.

key_work.title: Fritz Lang
key_work.brief_description: Fritz Lang was a visionary German director who established many science fiction tropes with his silent masterpiece Metropolis (1927). If that wasn’t enough, Lang’s seminal crime drama M (1931) was an early progenitor of psychological thrillers and serial killer films.

start.title: Metropolis
start.brief_description: In a futuristic city sharply divided between the working class and the city planners, the son of the city’s mastermind falls in love with a working class prophet who predicts the coming of a savior to mediate their differences.

constellations_other.name: Little, big worlds
constellations_other.description: Wes Anderson's stop-motion animation film draws on tried-and-true techniques that, despite the rise of computer-generated imagery, still inspire filmmakers and game-makers.

constellations_other.name: Arcades and AI
constellations_other.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

constellations_other.name: Webwurlds
constellations_other.description: Jess Johnson and Simon Ward's work is inspired by science fiction and fantasy. Johnson's hand-drawn illustrations are heavily detailed with geometric patterns and incorporate anthropomorphic characters amongst architectural environments in immersive other worlds.

links.description: Metropolis was set in 2026, with elements of the film’s production design going on to influence other genre classics Frankenstein and Blade Runner. The android Maria was one of the silver screen’s first robots and served as inspiration for C-3PO in Star Wars.

links.description: George Lucas’ uptight C-3PO become one of pop culture’s most enduring robots. When Madonna’s video for ‘Express Yourself’ (1989) came out a decade later, visions of C-3PO were invoked with both Lucas and Madonna drawing inspiration from Lang’s Metropolis.

links.description: David Fincher directed ‘Express Yourself’, which was inspired by the set design of Metropolis and reflected the German Expressionist cinema of the 1920s. Walter Ruttman’s Berlin: Symphony of a Metropolis is an excellent counterpoint to Lang’s expressionistic narrative drama.

links.description: Adapted from the novel by German writer, Thea von Harbou – the filmmaker’s then wife – Metropolis was Fritz Lang’s silent masterpiece. A pioneering work of imagination, it set the template for cinematic representations of future utopian/dystopian megasocieties beholden to technology and repressive class systems.
